characters: GEORGE AND DIEGO TAKING OVER THE WORLD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A majestic panorama of the lush green slopes that are the Columbian highlands.  A faint chopping sound IS HEARD and then another.  WHOOSH.  WHOOSH.  The view changes and tin dots appear on the hillside vegetation.  WHOOSH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We realize the dots are people.  Workers swinging long st machetes in slow methodical rhythm.  WHOOSH.  WHOOSH.  WE the South American Indian MEN clearly now.  Their tar sta teeth.  Their gaunt faces riddled with crow's feet.  Thei jaws chewing away on huge wads of coca leaves as they col the harvest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old rickety trucks carrying the huge green tractor-sized bales speed along the narrow road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bundles are undone and Columbian women separate out t leaves.  Tribes of underweight workers carry armload afte armload of the harvest and ritualistically dump them into gigantic cannibal pot which sits on top of a raging bonfi The leaves are being boiled down and a huge plume of smok streaks the sky.  Wizened Indios brave the heat and shove ashes into the pot to cool the solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A primitive but enormous makeshift lab contains all the equipment.  The machinery.  The solutions.  The over-size vats.  Dark-skinned bandoleros smoke cigarettes and sport automatic weapons at all the points of entry.  The coca i now a "basuco" paste and is being sent in for a wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A conveyor belt pours out brick after brick of pure cocai hydrochloride.  The bricks are wrapped, tied up, weighed, stamped with a "P" before being thrown into duffel bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small twin-engine Cessna is loaded with dozens of duffe bags and the plane takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cessna touches down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worksite is busy.  George is amongst other workers, working a summer job.  As George is taking five, he looks across the sight to Fred, who is sweeping up debris.  A l way from being the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stands in line to register for college, wearing hi Brooks Brothers suit, bowtie, and freshly Bryllcreamed ha The room is crowded and the line is long.  Bob Dylan's "Subterranean Homesick Blues" blares out of one of the ki transistor radios.  George looks around the room.  He is uncomfortable.  He catches his reflection in the shiny gl partition and stops.  He doesn't like what he sees. Something is not right.  He looks like everyone else.  Sa cookie-cutter hair, same cookie-cutter clothes, same cook cutter faces.  He's a carbon copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next. It's George's turn but he doesn't hear it.  "Twenty years schooling and they put you on a day shift."  The words hi him like a tone of bricks as he continues to stare at his reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was standing there, and it was like the outside of me and the inside of me didn't match, you know?  And then I looked around the room and it hit me.  I saw my whole life.  Where I was gonna live, what type of car I'd drive, who my neighbors would be.  I saw it all and I didn't want it.  Not that life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sits with Fred.  It's breaktime and Fred eats from lunch box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something out there for me, Dad. Something different.  Something free form, you know?  Something for me, and college just isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad.  You would have been the first one in the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  You want me to get your old job back?  Because I could, you know, I could put in that word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Dad.  I don't want to...I mean, I just don't want... It's obvious to Fred that his son doesn't want to be like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to California.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: George and Tuna, now 21-years old, struggle with their ba Their new place is a tackily furnished, two-story apartme with small balconies and a view of the ocean.  As George Tuna struggle with the bags, two California beauties appe on the balcony next door: BARBARA BUCKLEY, 20, and MARIA GONZALES, 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys need some help? George and Tuna share a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about you, but I think we're gonna like it here.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Barbara and Maria introduce George and Tuna around to the Manhattan Beach regulars.  They are immediately accepted despite their ill fitting shorts and Tuna's unhip black socks.  The beach scene is one big party.  Lots of beer, music, bikinis, and good times.  By the end of the day, George and Tuna have a hundred new friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California was like nothing I'd ever experienced.  The people were liberated and independent and full of new ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They used words like "right on," "groovy," and "solid."  The women are all beautiful and seemed to share the same occupation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a flight attendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a flight attendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a flight attendant. The weed comes out and is passed around.  Pipes.  Joints. Bongs.  In SLOW MOTION, Barbara takes a huge hit of grass grabs George's face, french kissing him, and giving him a huge shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Barbara are sleeping late.  Their bodies intertwined beneath the sheets.  A slam of the front door wakes them up.  It's Tuna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wake up.  Come on, you two lovebirds.  Hurry, I want to show you something. George and Barbara shake cobwebs out and stumble into the kitchen to find Tuna holding a brown paper shopping bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figured it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figured what out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how we were wondering what we were going to do for money?  Being how we don't want to get jobs and whatnot? Well, check this out. Tuna takes the paper bag and empties its contents on the kitchen table.  It's a grey mound of stocky, seedy mariju Barbara examines the reefer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuna, this is crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's not the greatest.  It's commercial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's oregano.  You got ripped off, pal. What are you gonna do with all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sell it.  I got it all figured out. We make three finger lids and sell them on the beach.  We move all of it.  We've made ourselves a hundred bucks.  Or a lot of weed for our head.  What do you think?  Not bad, huh?  I got the baggies and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't sell this to your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man.  Fuck you guys.  I have this great idea and you guys have to be all skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you really wanna score some dope, I got the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, Barbara and Tuna stop outside the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure this guy is cool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beauty parlor for men?  Sounds pretty queer. They walk in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, Tuna and Barbara enter.  The Whipping Post is California's first male hair salon.  George looks around the customer's being pampered.  Haircuts, pedicures, manicures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like this back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek! DEREK FOREAL is a curious man.  Daringly effeminate, especially for the sixties, he is always surrounded by beautiful women.  As he sees Barbara, he stops his haircu and runs to embrace her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbie! Derek's female entourage rush over as well.  Kisses all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, this is the new man, huh?  He's cute! George and Tuna stick out there hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuna, oh my.  Enchante, George.  Barbie, he's yummy.  He looks like a Ken doll. Oooh, Ken and Barbie.  It's perfect. Alright, girls, give me five minutes. Derek makes dismissing gestures and the girls scatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone, shoo!  You, too, Barbie.  I want to talk to the boys alone. After the girls leave, Derek closes the partition and his playful demeanor changes.  He's all business now.

dialogues.text: What can I do for you guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want some grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you want.  But, first of all, are you cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you are, you have to tell me. If not, it's entrapment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not cops.  We're from Massachusettes.  I mean, does he look like a cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess not.  Okay.  You know, you're very lucky you're friends of Barbie's. If you weren't, I'd never talk to you. Derek pulls a television-sized brick of quality marijuana from under a sink and sets it down in front of George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.  That's more than we had in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't nickel and dime.  You want it or not? George and Tuna look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take it.

dialogues.text: George walks in to find Tuna and Maria sitting with KEVIN DULLI, an old friend from back east.  He's sitting in fro of a water pipe and coughing his ass off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what the cat dragged in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit, Dulli.  What the hell are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell you.  I was walking down the beach, minding my business, when who did I see but this fucking guy.  I didn't know you guys were living in California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but what are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on vacation.  On my way back to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This calls for a joint.  You want to do the honors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, man.  I'm too fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice weed, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck yeah.  I never seen nothing like it.  I'm fucking wasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G-d, I'm stoned.  I'm stoned.  I'm really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stoned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish there was shit like this back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, yeah.  Do you know how much money I could make if I had this stuff back east?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit, Kevin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When there's something to move, it's too easy not to.  Do you know how many colleges are in a twenty mile radius? U. Mass, Amherst, B.U....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith.  Hampshire....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  And Holyoke.  There are a hundred thousand rich kids with their parents' money to spend, but there's never anything available.  Nothing good, anyway.  I'm paying four hundred dollars for shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek, George and Barbara sit around.  The blinds are dra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way we figure it, Barbara flies to Boston twice a week.  Two bags per flight.  Twenty-five pounds in each bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding, right?  That's a hundred pounds a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, it's a lot of weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna call it California sinsemilla.  Sounds exotic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, Derek, it will sell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the best part.  We can charge five-hundred a pound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, George, no one is going to pay that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's already been negotiated.  It's done.  The money is there waiting. Derek looks at Barbara.  She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness is right.  If you do the math, that's over thirty grand a week profit. I want you to be my partner on this, Derek.  Fifty-fifty.  That's fifteen thousand a week for you, my friend.  In your pocket, free and clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I only deal with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and me.  No one else. Derek thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna work, Derek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  East coast.  Airplanes. It all sounds pretty risky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a flight attendant.  They don't check her bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George drops Barbara off in her uniform curbside.  They k and she walks away with two big, red Samsonites.  She che them with a SKYCAP and tips him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge jet goes right to left through frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is greeted by KEVIN DULLI with a hug.  A baggage claim check is slipped into Kevin's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Barbara's two red Samsonites being taken off the b by Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same scene repeated, except different clothes on all.  Ma Kevin is dressed a little better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same scene repeated, same things changed again; now K is definitely dressed a little better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?  I can only take two bags, and I can't fly back here everyday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but I've got a feeding frenzy on my hands.  Tell George this is small potatoes.  We're missing out on some serious cash.  You tell George.  He'll think of something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Well, that's all I really wanted to say.  So, okay, then. He moves down the steps and heads for the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I'm fine.  I'm good.

dialogues.text: We take off from Lauderdale, Sunday, refuel, and be in Medellin by Monday.

dialogues.text: Yeah.  Go out there, check it out, see what it's like.  I've got some stuff to do this week, but I'm thinking maybe Thursday.  Thursday after school.

Kevin and Leon stick their fists out of the airplane in triumph.  The men quickly unload the plane into the trunk two Broncos and the back of a truck.

dialogues.text: Are we good?  Yeah, we're good.  We're beautiful.  We're perfect.  This is A grade, one-hundred percent pure Colombian cocaine, Ladies and Gentlemen. Disco shit.  Pure as the driven snow. Good riddance. He looks the boys over.

dialogues.text: You saved my life, Dulli.  You'll never fucking know.  All you guys.  Everyone just got a raise.  Instead of ten percent, you get fifteen.

dialogues.text: Nine-year old Kristina Sunshine Jung sits on the front po as the sun goes down.  Her bags are packed and ready to g

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: visibly moved.

dialogues.text: I remember how important the job we did was. How if it weren't for us, people would freeze to death.  I thought you were the strongest man in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: That was a beautiful message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant every word of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Dad.  I knew that.

In the letter, Diego offers make a deal.  In exchange for immunity, Diego will rat ou the entire cocaine business.  Americans, Colombians, Nori Escobar, everybody.  Just let him free.

dialogues.text: Mr. Jung, can you describe the circumstances of how you began talking about cocaine with Mr. Delgado?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shortly after I arrived at Danbury Federal Correctional Institute I related to Diego that the crime I was in for was smuggling marijuana. Diego told me he had high level connections in Colombia and they needed to find someone to help them transport cocaine into America...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first run was fifteen kilos, which we smuggled into Logan Airport in hard shelled suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wrapped the cocaine in kitchen cabinet paper, and duct tape, that way if there were any dogs in customs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I introduced Diego to a pilot named Jack Stevens, who helped us fly 300 kilos of cocaine per week into the United States via twin-engine Cessnas.  Jack would fly into North Carolina, we'd meet him there and drive it down to different distribution points...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never met Pablo Escobar.  Diego Delgado was my only connection to cocaine from Colombia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego convinced me to keep most of my money in a Panamanian bank.  Diego had a close relationship with Manuel Noriega. In exchange for allowing us to keep our money there, we paid him a percentage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was an 85% chance that if you snorted cocaine between 1977-1984, it was ours. Initially with my LA connections, we invented the marketplace.  In 1977, there was no other real competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first year we made about 100 million dollars between us.  It was an expensive operation.  Eventually we built up to three different pilots doing multiple runs per week, connections on both coasts, everything was running smooth. We were like a corporation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he was very anti-government.  He talked about revolution, forming his own country or island, he was looking for power as well as money.  I was just looking for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disliked the United States, thought it was a police state.  He hoped that by flooding the country with cocaine, it would disrupt the political system and tear down the morality of the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, Derek Foreal was my connection, I met him back in 1968 when I first moved to Manhattan Beach.  It was Foreal's marijuana connections that kicked off our cocaine market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it was my idea to bring the kilos to Los Angeles.  When Diego finally got Derek Foreal's name from me, it was only a matter of months before he'd cut me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure how my relationship with my daughter and ex-wife have anything to do with this trial.  I mean we're here to talk about Diego Delgado, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we are Mr. Jung. We come out of the montage, the defense attorney Diego Delgado, Joe Calibanos, a sleazy-Greek-like-ex-basketball weight lifter guy is now doing the questioning.

dialogues.text: Mr. Jung, you're a convicted felon, correct?

dialogues.text: Do you have any agreement or understanding whatsoever with the United States government in regards to your testimony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something about vengance being best served cold.

dialogues.text: Really.  Are you getting paid, Mr. Jung?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jung, don't you have an agreement or understanding with the United States Government in connection with your testimony in this case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

I don't know if the parole board, the judge, the pope or Jesus Christ himself can get me out of here.  I have a really bad record, I'm not sure what's going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you do have an agreement with the United States Government, Mr. Jung, correct? George can't respond.  Looks to Diego.  Looks from the ju the judge, George is on the spotlight and it's uncomforta He feels suddenly sleazy.

dialogues.text: I thought so.  No more questions. Silence.  The judge tells George he can step down.  Calib laughs quietly with associates.  George is bummed.  He wa by Diego.  They look at each other.

dialogues.text: You shouldn't have taken the 30 million, Diego, I was out. George is lead away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to see my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GUARDS are rounding up the other prisoners and escort them inside, but George is still planting sunflowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, George, five more minutes, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jung. Kristina grabs her papers and moves to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss? He presses the buzzer again, but she just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss?  Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.  I love you so much.  You've got to know that.  You've got to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Dad.  I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After everything.  After everything, the only thing left out of my whole life is you. Kristina looks at her father, smiles, and disappears.  Th was no Kristina.  The guard continues to tap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George?  George, come on.  It's getting dark. George looks up to find a prison guard.  His name is GUS, he helps George to his feet.

dialogues.text: Okay, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's visiting me.

dialogues.text: We'll do that tomorrow, okay?  It's lockdown time. The shadows grow long, and Gus leads George down a cement path that cuts through the grass.  The huge structure of Otisville looms dark against the sky, and Gus and George the long walk back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing outside the fences, Kristina smokes a cigarette she watches her father being led away.  After a few momen she turns around, walks to her car and gets in.  Time to home.  And as the brown Mazda pulls out of the driveway, taillights turn red, growing smaller and smaller, until t finally disappear. THE END.
